sect3.title: Program Files
sect3.para: free, kill, oldps, pgrep, pkill, ps, skill, snice, sysctl, tload, top, uptime, vmstat, w and watch

sect4.title: free
sect4.para: free displays the total amount of free and used physical and swap memory in the system, as well as the shared memory and buffers used by the kernel.

sect4.title: oldps and ps
sect4.para: ps gives a snapshot of the current processes.

sect4.title: pgrep
sect4.para: pgrep looks up processes based on name and other attributes

sect4.title: pkill
sect4.para: pkill signals processes based on name and other attributes

sect4.title: skill
sect4.para: skill sends signals to process matching a criteria.

sect4.title: snice
sect4.para: snice changes the scheduling priority for process matching a criteria.

sect4.title: sysctl
sect4.para: sysctl modifies kernel parameters at runtime.

sect4.title: tload
sect4.para: tload prints a graph of the current system load average to the specified tty (or the tty of the tload process if none is specified).

sect4.title: top
sect4.para: top provides an ongoing look at processor activity in real time.

sect4.title: uptime
sect4.para: uptime gives a one line display of the following information: the current time, how long the system has been running, how many users are currently logged on, and the system load averages for the past 1, 5, and 15 minutes.

sect4.title: vmstat
sect4.para: vmstat reports information about processes, memory, paging, block IO, traps, and cpu activity.

sect4.title: w
sect4.para: w displays information about the users currently on the machine, and their processes.

sect4.title: watch
sect4.para: watch runs command repeatedly, displaying its output (the first screen full).

sect4.title: libproc
sect4.para: libproc is the library against which most of the programs in this set are linked to save disk space by implementing common functions only once.
